SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Which phrase best expresses the central conflict of the passage?

A.Choice: Person versus self

B.Choice: Person versus society

C.Choice: Person versus nature

D.Choice: Person versus destiny

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What does the narrator first think when the woman does not give up her seat?

A.Choice: The woman is daydreaming.

B.Choice: The woman must not know the law.

C.Choice: The woman is too tired to change places.

D.Choice: The woman must not agree with the law.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: In paragraph 2, the word l͟o͟o͟m͟i͟n͟g creates a sense of

A.Choice: surprise.

B.Choice: frustration.

C.Choice: confrontation.

D.Choice: disappointment.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The following paragraph was taken from a newspaper account of the same events described in the passage.

:box:The commute home from work was disrupted for some bus travelers in the city yesterday afternoon. A woman onboard a bus refused to give up her seat to a white passenger. After repeated warnings, police were summoned. They removed the woman from the bus, which resumed its normal operations.
How does the passage differ from the newspaper account?

A.Choice: The newspaper account includes details about the arrival of the police.

B.Choice: The passage focuses on the day the woman refused to give up her seat.

C.Choice: The newspaper account mentions commuting troubles the events caused.

D.Choice: The passage reveals the emotional effect of the events on the other bus riders.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Which phrase best describes the second bus driver in the passage?

A.Choice: Gruff, because of the lack of riders that day

B.Choice: Offended, because the uncle asks him a question

C.Choice: Curious, because of the information in the newspaper

D.Choice: Perceptive, because he is aware that the woman is being tried in court

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text, including those from diverse cultures.
Content: Which method did the author use to illustrate that most characters in the passage accept the city law of the time?

A.Choice: Describing the uncle’s sigh of relief when the woman is removed from the bus

B.Choice: Including the police officer’s response to a surprising question the woman asks

C.Choice: Emphasizing the bus driver’s angry threat to have the woman arrested

D.Choice: Portraying the people’s obvious expectations that the woman follow orders

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 8.
:box:The driver glared at the woman, then turned and marched up the aisle and out of the bus.
The author uses the word m͟a͟r͟c͟h͟e͟d most likely to

A.Choice: indicate that the woman has defeated the driver.

B.Choice: suggest that the driver is going to quit his job.

C.Choice: indicate that others on the bus support the driver.

D.Choice: suggest that the driver is angered by the woman.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Paragraph 17 is important to the plot because it shows that the bus

A.Choice: has a different driver than usual.

B.Choice: always follows its usual schedule.

C.Choice: is usually full when people leave work.

D.Choice: provides transportation throughout the day.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Which quotation from the passage best shows the lasting effect of the events on the narrator?

A.Choice: “‘Now we’re going to be late for supper.’” (paragraph 9)

B.Choice: “‘If we weren’t so far from home, I’d say we could get out and walk.’” (paragraph 9)

C.Choice: “For the first time in my life, I began to think about the different rules that apply to different people.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “As my uncle resumed reading his newspaper, I wondered briefly if I should catch up on my homework.” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Details in the last paragraph of the passage suggest that

A.Choice: the woman had intended to hurt the bus company.

B.Choice: the people on the bus will join those refusing to ride the bus and the bus company’s drivers will be fired.

C.Choice: the bus company’s policy will change because it is losing money since the woman captured the public’s attention.

D.Choice: the decision in the court case will force the bus company to change.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the poem, which water source affects the water level in the small pool?

A.Choice: Water from the rivulet

B.Choice: Water from the rain

C.Choice: Water from the ocean

D.Choice: Water from the sea

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence best summarizes lines 1–7?

A.Choice: A drop of rain collects in a small pool.

B.Choice: A wide river rushes over different kinds of stones.

C.Choice: A creek fills a dry pool near a meadow.

D.Choice: A little stream passes through a field of grass.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: In line 6, the word t͟h͟r͟e͟a͟d refers to

A.Choice: the sound made by the water.

B.Choice: the size of the stream of water.

C.Choice: the stones rolling in the moving water.

D.Choice: the grass growing along the edge of the water.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The rivulet is unable to reach the ocean because it

A.Choice: collects in a pool.

B.Choice: is not long enough.

C.Choice: flows under the ground.

D.Choice: evaporates in the sunlight.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read lines 9–11.

:box:important waters, it says,
are waiting for it
out at sea.
What do these lines tell readers about the rivulet?

A.Choice: Where the rivulet wants to go

B.Choice: Why the rivulet will fail to reach the ocean

C.Choice: Why the waters are essential to the rivulet

D.Choice: What to expect once the rivulet reaches the sea

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which characteristic best describes the rivulet?

A.Choice: Successful

B.Choice: Confused

C.Choice: Motivated

D.Choice: Disappointed

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which pair of lines best expresses how the speaker feels about the rivulet?

A.Choice: Lines 3 and 4

B.Choice: Lines 6 and 7

C.Choice: Lines 15 and 16

D.Choice: Lines 19 and 20

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The rivulet is in a hurry because it believes that the

A.Choice: pool is dry.

B.Choice: fountain is near.

C.Choice: ocean is waiting.

D.Choice: rain is approaching.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which description best represents the main topic of the article?

A.Choice: The challenges of a blind artist growing up in Turkey

B.Choice: The participation of a blind artist in scientific experiments

C.Choice: The abilities of a blind artist from Turkey

D.Choice: The process a blind artist uses to create his paintings

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In paragraph 3, the author compares Armagan touching his drawings to

A.Choice: reading books that are printed in Braille.

B.Choice: etching an image into canvas.

C.Choice: applying colors to paintings.

D.Choice: remembering objects that have been touched before.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: The author’s main purpose for writing the article is most likely to

A.Choice: inform readers about the creative process of an artist.

B.Choice: explain to readers how a part of the human brain works.

C.Choice: instill in readers an appreciation for individual accomplishment.

D.Choice: persuade readers to celebrate an artist for his work.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on paragraph 3, readers can conclude that Armagan’s paintings

A.Choice: are especially colorful.

B.Choice: usually resemble the drawings of others.

C.Choice: are rarely inspired by memories.

D.Choice: take along time to complete.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 5, which words help readers understand the meaning of p͟e͟r͟s͟p͟e͟c͟t͟i͟v͟e͟s?

A.Choice: “amazed the scientists”

B.Choice: “different points of view”

C.Choice: “represent these shapes”

D.Choice: “much of human vision”

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to paragraph 6, the visual cortex is sometimes referred to as “ ‘the Mind’s Eye’” because it

A.Choice: is part of the brain.

B.Choice: provides additional light for seeing in the dark.

C.Choice: is constantly active.

D.Choice: interprets information gained from the sense of sight.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: Which word best describes the author’s tone throughout the article?

A.Choice: Formal

B.Choice: Impressed

C.Choice: Envious

D.Choice: Sympathetic

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which idea is important in both articles?

A.Choice: Homeschooling prevents development of meaningful relationships.

B.Choice: Homeschooling provides the best preparation for college.

C.Choice: Homeschooling is more academically challenging than public schooling.

D.Choice: Homeschooling is difficult for many people to understand.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Which factor motivated the authors of both articles to attend public school?

A.Choice: Seeking friends

B.Choice: Overcoming shyness

C.Choice: Becoming a teenager

D.Choice: Needing specialized classes

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which argument does Kamala Baudichon use to suggest homeschooling is more challenging than public schooling?

A.Choice: Homeschoolers take few breaks during the day.

B.Choice: Public school peers encourage each other.

C.Choice: Homeschoolers study a classical curriculum.

D.Choice: Public school has easier assignments.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 2, the phrase “create your own gravity” means homeschoolers must

A.Choice: discipline themselves to study independently.

B.Choice: take all subjects seriously.

C.Choice: discover for themselves how to make friends.

D.Choice: stay on a rigid schedule.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Why did Kamala Baudichon attend public high school?

A.Choice: She wanted to change her image as an uncommitted homeschooled student.

B.Choice: She lacked interest in the classical literature her mother required her to read.

C.Choice: She wanted to experience the challenges of a larger social network.

D.Choice: She lacked the organizational skill necessary to succeed as a homeschooled student.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In paragraph 3, what did Kamala Baudichon’s mother mean when she said public school teachers “specialize in their subjects”?

A.Choice: They bring varied teaching styles to public schools.

B.Choice: They think all of their students are uniquely talented.

C.Choice: They devote time exclusively to particular areas of study.

D.Choice: They have many years of teaching experience in public schools.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: In contrast to Kamala Baudichon’s opinion, Nicole Perkins believes that homeschooling

A.Choice: limited her social connections.

B.Choice: helped her avoid negative influences.

C.Choice: prepared her well for the future.

D.Choice: enabled her to form strong friendships.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: In her early years, how did Nicole Perkins feel when people asked which type of school she attended?

A.Choice: Uncomfortable

B.Choice: Isolated

C.Choice: Uninterested

D.Choice: Irritated

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: Based on her article, readers can conclude that Nicole Perkins believes

A.Choice: public schools have excellent instructors.

B.Choice: close friends significantly influence students.

C.Choice: opportunities to make acquaintances increase with age.

D.Choice: classroom experience with older students improves performance.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Which phrase best describes what r͟e͟v͟e͟r͟t͟ ͟t͟o means in paragraph 6?

A.Choice: Refer to something that has been said before

B.Choice: Correspond about something in secret

C.Choice: Rewrite something to improve its effectiveness

D.Choice: Laugh at something with a companion

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 9, a͟n͟o͟n͟y͟m͟o͟u͟s͟l͟y means

A.Choice: with deep thought.

B.Choice: without being known.

C.Choice: with great confusion.

D.Choice: without much excitement.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: Which statement best describes Nicole Perkins’ tone in “What School Do You Go To?”

A.Choice: She uses humor to discuss a serious situation.

B.Choice: She writes formally to convey important information.

C.Choice: She writes conversationally to connect with readers.

D.Choice: She uses slang expressions to impress young readers.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Nicole Perkins quit high school after one term because she

A.Choice: appreciated a more flexible schedule.

B.Choice: needed to be academically challenged.

C.Choice: preferred having a few close friends.

D.Choice: felt prepared to enroll in college classes.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Which phrase means the same as d͟u͟a͟l͟l͟y͟ ͟e͟n͟r͟o͟l͟l͟e͟d in paragraph 11?

A.Choice: Competing with older students and meeting deadlines

B.Choice: Taking at least two classes at the same time

C.Choice: Attending a college and a university

D.Choice: Working full time while taking classes

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which paragraph best implies Nicole Perkins has been a successful student?

A.Choice: Paragraph 8

B.Choice: Paragraph 9

C.Choice: Paragraph 10

D.Choice: Paragraph 11

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which event in the article indicates the point when Nicole Perkins realized she prefers homeschooling over public high school?

A.Choice: Attending high school for one term

B.Choice: Falling in love with her college classes

C.Choice: Joining emotional discussions with friends

D.Choice: Having a meltdown before her freshman year in high school

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence best expresses an important message in both articles?

A.Choice: Seeking challenges makes a person stronger.

B.Choice: Clear expectations help people become more confident.

C.Choice: Different educational approaches offer different advantages.

D.Choice: Proceeding carefully with major life changes is important.
